text: Thanks!

Hello community!

If I wanted to build a listing page of multiple blogs sorted by due date meaning that:
• On certain date blog A could have 8 posts and blog B could show 1. 
• On other  date blog A could have 2 posts and blog B could show 7.
Is there a way to do that?
There’s no way to use HubL macros or variables inside of a module CSS file, right?
no, hubl can be used inside a script tag in module.html
not a module file, correct
css+hubl though will work
Yeah. Sad.

Is there any way to include HubL custom variables in a custom section? i.e. if I include a file with a custom HubL color variable in a template and have the custom section in the template, and am using the variable for the background color in the custom section, it works fine when you create a new page using that template. But if you add the section to a page through the page editor, it doesn't recognize the color variable and assigns no color. I have “fixed” this by assigning a short-circuit fallback color, but that kind of defeats the purpose of using variables, since it will always use that manual fallback in this case.
I usually create a separate CSS+HubL file that I bind to the module instead of using the default css tab just because I need to use Hubl
Yeah, I kind of like that idea. It's going to make it harder to find/understand/edit for non-developers though. Though hopefully they won't be in there editing stuff anyway.

Offhand, do you know the difference between using a `{{ require_css() }}`  in the module.html and just adding it as a file asset in the module/meta.json, in terms of how/where it gets added to the html?
if you add it as a file you're sure that the file will get loaded just once even if you have multiple instances of the module, with the require_css/scope_css I think it will be loaded multiple times

*Need dynamic CSS?* bind hubl values to css variables in module.html file
*Need dynamic JS?* bind hubl values to data attributes in module.html file and snag em with js

another example: I have css snippets in a macros file to handle custom styles. Use the import tag and have at it
`{% import '../../macros/css_snippets.html' as css_snippets %}`
Yeah, I was hoping you could use import or include in a module.css file, but no go.

<@U03HR644BMX> So when the section is added to an existing page, the variable passed in as context isn't recognized?  Is it possible to assign the variable in a global CSS file and pass a class name via the section?
{% module_attribute 'background_color' %}{{ context.background_color || 'light' }}{% end_module_attribute %}
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/cms/hubl/tags/dnd-areas#background-color>
Is it possible to limit the background color options available in the page editor for sections using the fields.json in the theme e.g. only 3 hex codes for light, gray or dark as options?

css variable: hubl variable

I think that should get what you want, then you can reference css variable anywhere if the stylesheet is loaded
Yeah, I have a CSS variable color system set up, but sadly you can't reference CSS variables in things like section backgrounds, you have to provide hex/rgb directly.
